Courtesy of the councilrsquos website, I am more than familiar with the surprisingly mild weather to be had in Shetland, but it still hardly seems possible that the most melancholic copper since the last one could go about year round without a scarf, never mind a bobble hat.Now he even has the wonderful DS Alison ldquoTosh McIntoshfollowing in his chilly footsteps, her neck bare to the elements despite the brooding skies. Maybe their shared burning sense of outrage keeps them warm.If so, they would have been toasty by the end of episode one of this, the fth series of the crime drama drawn from the novels of Ann Cleeves, with added tales from lead writer David Kane. A jogger has found a severed lower arm on a beach. Perezand his team wonder initiallyit has washed there from Norway, the implication being that nothing like this could surely happen in Shetland. How sweet, given the islandsrsquo murder rate in the last couple of years could have given The Wirersquos Baltimore a run for its money.Douglas Henshall on theof PerezWhen a dog finds a head in a bag , Perez has the look of a man who knows something wicked has his way come. He is never happier than when he is miserable, and this case looks particularly grim, even before the mother of the victim, a -year-old man born in Nigeria, turns up to accusing Perez and the islanders of closing ranks. ldquoI donrsquot turn a blind eye to anything, seethes the scarfless one.What was going on  Was it a fish scam  If not, would that be the ultimate red herring  If not fish, drugs  Worse Thank the Lord for Shetlandrsquos bleak as the grave humour, which balances out the misery while ensuring there are no sharp lurches in tone. The Jimmy-Duncan double dad act is still going strong, with the latter coming to live with Perez after his partner finds another man. ldquoShersquos leaving Scotland, says Duncan. ldquoWi him  asks Perez. ldquoNo, wirsquo the big top.Elsewhere, Tosh has been digging into the victimrsquos social media accounts but there is nothing to suggest he was involved with drugs. ldquoThen again, she muses, "I donrsquot suppose Pablo Escobarrsquos Facebook page did either.Ann Cleeves on writing the final Shetland bookThere were some ldquohang on a wee minute moments that jarred, such as Perez and the victimrsquos mother, Oliviajust happening to go into the bar where some obvious wrong lsquouns were having a heated argument relevant to the case. If that seemed rather too convenient, later identying the place from a song that was playing in the background when Perez was in was even more far fetched. Unless, of course, pubs in Shetland only have one tune, like the disco in Father Ted.TV series brings visitorsgaloreViewers can forgive the drama pulling the odd fast one now and again because there is so much going on. Although Shetland tells a single story over six hours, a long time in TV drama, it barely draws breath, throwing in one twist after another, and many an ldquoissue besides, without ever seeming heavy-handed. This series looks like it will be shining a light in some very dark corners, including racism and misogyny.It would be hard going, and it sometimes is, without the company of Perez and his team, especially Sergeant Billy, ing as a one man Greek chorus, announcing the next woe to come along. I bet Billy wears a scarf to defend himself against the chill winds of mans inhumanity to man. You should try it, Jimmy.

title: diageos-whisky-tourism-centre-plan-for-former-house-of-fraser-in-princes-street-unveiled
story: The attraction is intended to be the focal point of a pound million investment in Scotch whisky tourism by Diageo, the drinksgiant said.The planning application, jointly submitted by Diageo and the building owner Parabola, sets out proposals for aseven-floor visitor experience at  Princes Street.The proposals would see the "meticulous restoration of the building with its many beautul heritage features preserved where possible and integrated into the new development".This will include restoring the famous clock on the corner of Princes Street and Hope Street ndashknown locally as the Binns corner after the former department store - which was earlier an Edinburgh institution and traditional meeting point for city residents.Most recently it was home to House of Fraser.Read more: Diageo very confident over Princes Street Johnnie Walker whisky centre bidIt says it will include a"multi-sensory, immersive visitor experience" across three floors, guiding people through the  year history of the brand, the art and science of whisky-making, and taking them on a journey through the flavours of Scotland.Diageo said the centre will be aflexible events space for staging music, theatre, arts and community events, making the venue part of the thriving cultural le of the city.It will also house abar academy that will be a home for Diageorsquos Learning for Le programme, which creates training and employment opportunities in the hospitality industry for unemployed people, and works to improve hospitality standards and promotes the responsible serving and consumption of alcohol.There will also be roof-top bars with views of Edinburgh Castle and across the city skyline to east, west and north, "with the intention of making it one of the worldrsquos most extraordinary iconic hospitality destinations".Read moreDiageo plays down Brexit impact as shares hit all-time highEconomic projections for the plan indicate it will create between  and  full time equivalent jobs and generate poundm in tourism spend.It is claimed the development also creates a powerful strategic opportunity for Edinburgh city centre, establishing a major attraction in the west end, helping to balance visitor footfall across the city.David Cutter, hairman of Diageo in Scotland, said: "We are incredibly excited to be able to submit our plans for the Johnnie Walker visitor experience in Edinburgh."The location is one of Edinburghrsquos most exceptional landmark buildings and we plan to restore it to its former glory as a cornerstone of the city and a thriving part of its cultural and social le."We have the most passionate and skilled whisky-makers in the world here in Scotland and we want to celebrate their craft and everything that is great about Scotland and whisky.Read more:Scotch giant fears for small firms as Brexit saga drags onTony Hordon, managing director of Parabola, said: "With Diageo and their vision, we believe we have a use which will not only protect the building for many years to come, but it also celebrates the building, its history, and its heritage."Diageo is currently investing over poundmin Scotch whisky experiences in Scotland.As well as the Edinburgh location, the company is also investing to transform its existing  distillery visitor attractions across Scotland and a poundminvestment to reopen the iconic distilleries of Port Ellen and Brora.

title: mps-must-hold-their-nerve-over-brexit-says-theresa-may
story: Theresa May is due to update the Commons later on the latest developments in negotiations with Brussels and Dublin, as the sides try to find a way through the impasse on measures for the Irish border.Downing Street said Mrs Mays statement, which comes a day earlier than expected, will give MPs more time to "digest the content" ahead of a series of expected Commons votes on Thursday.:Nicola Sturgeon: Scotland will be independent in five yearsMrs May is expected to say: "The talks are at a crucial stage. We now all need to hold our nerve to get the changes this House has required and deliver Brexit on time."By getting the changes we need to the backstop by protecting and enhancing workers rights and environmental protections and by enhancing the role of Parliament in the next phase of negotiations I believe we can reach a deal that this House can support."Talks are continuing apace between the UK and EU, with Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay and Mrs Mays de facto deputy, David Lidington, meeting MEPs in Strasbourg on Tuesday.Mr Barclay was said to have held "constructive" talks on Monday night with the EUs chief negotiator Michel Barnier in Brussels.The pair agreed to further meetings in the coming days, while their teams will continue to work to find a way forward.:David Watt: If the boss of Jaguar Land Rover says job losses are likely, then believe him, not a spokesperson for the European Research GroupMeanwhile, Sky News reported the former president of the European Council, Herman Van Rompuy, had dinner with Mr Lidington in Brussels on Monday night.Mr Van Rompuy has been tipped as a potential "influencer" to break the Brexit deadlock, the broadcaster reported.Negotiations of a kind have also been taking place back in Westminster, with an exchange of letters between Mrs May and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn.However, a Cabinet minister insisted there is "no chance" of Mrs May accepting Labours vision for leaving the EU, despite speculation she could soften her stance on customs union membership.In an exclusive interview with the Press Association, Commons leader Andrea Leadsom dismissed the prospect of Mrs May adopting Mr Corbyns "world view".Mrs Leadsom, an ardent Leaver, said she would stay in the Cabinet to help Mrs May deliver Brexit and denied that the PM was softening her stance over a customs union in a letter to Mr Corbyn.Mrs Mays reply sparked concern among Conservative Brexiteers that the Prime Minister could concede too much ground to Labour in an attempt to win cross-party backing for a deal with Brussels.Mrs Leadsom said: "I think shes making quite clear that what Corbyn is demanding is actually not as good as what the Prime Ministers deal is offering."So he wants a customs union and he is unclear as to whether that means he also wants an independent trade policy."Hes unclear as to whether he also wants to stop free movement, and of course the EUs view would be, well,youre in the customs union then you have free movement and you abide by the common external tarf."I think theres no doubt that what the Prime Minister is offering is better than what Corbyn is demanding, which simply begs the question,they like it, why dont they vote for it "Mrs Leadsom said there was "no chance" Mrs May would adopt Mr Corbyns "view of the world", adding: "The Prime Minister has been absolutely clear were leaving the EU, were leaving the customs union, were leaving the single market."The frontbencher refused to say what the cut-off date would be for the necessary legislation to get through the Commons to allow the UK to leave the EU as planned on March .She said it was possible to pass bills "quite quickly" with "goodwill" from the Commons and Lords, but added: "Its just not possible to say how quickly it could be done."

title: george-clooney-meghan-markle-vilified-like-princess-diana
story: But now one of the worldrsquos most famous men has warned that the mediarsquos treatment of the Duchess of Sussex is headed down a dark path and compared it to the attention received by the late Princess Diana.Holywood star George Clooney has said that the duchess is being ldquopursued and vilied and warned that history was in danger of repeating itself, adding ldquowersquove seen how that ends.Princess Diana was famously one of the most photographed women in the world and had an uneasy relationship with the media.While she courted publicity following the break-up of her marriage to Prince Charles, she was pursued relentlessly by paparazzi photographers, including on the night of her fatal crash in Paris.Mr Clooney is a friend of Harry and Meghan and he and his human rights lawyer we, Amal, attended the royal wedding in May last year.His intervention comes amid reports of a rt between the duchess, who is pregnant, and her father, Thomas.Over the weekend a newspaper published a deeply personal letter allegedly written by the duchess to her father in August, months after he missed her wedding.After joking about a report suggesting he would be named godfather to Harry and Meghanrsquos baby, Mr Clooney, who was speaking at an event in Los Angeles, said: ldquoI do want to say, I just saw this piece.ldquoTheyrsquore just chasing Meghan Markle everywhere, shersquos been pursued and vilied. Shersquos a woman who is seven months pregnant and she is being pursued and vilied and chased in the same way that Diana was, and itrsquos history repeating itself.ldquoAnd wersquove seen how that ends. I canrsquot tell you how frustrating it is to see that. Yoursquore taking a letter from a daughter to a father and broadcasting it everywhere.ldquoShersquos getting a raw deal there, itrsquos irresponsible. Irsquom sort of surprised by that.The duchess, , has had to learn quickly how to cope with the scrutiny which comes from being a member of the Royal Family, despite her previous fame.The former Suits actress is estranged from her father after a string of high-profile incidents since she became engaged to Harry.The prince has previously hit out at photographers for the way in which they pursued his mother.Kensington Palace has also tried to take a strong line, with an official letter written by Prince Harryrsquos communications secretary, Jason Knauf, describing how Mr Markle had been ldquofollowed and harassed by photographers and journalists.The letter urged editors not to publish pictures of Mr Markle and called on them to stop pursuing him.Days before his daughter was due to marry into the Royal Family, Mr Markle staged paparazzi photos of himself being fitted for a suit for the royal wedding, exercising and reading a book on English landmarks.He has previously said his relationship with his daughter has broken down and has made public appeals for her to get in touch with him, including an appearance on Good Morning Britain.Mr Markle, speaking to the Mail On Sunday this week, dismissed claims he has not attempted to contact his daughter.An unnamed friend of Los Angeles-born Meghan told US magazine People: ldquoHersquos never called hersquos never texted. Itrsquos super painful.Five nameless friends of the duchess spoke to People in an effort to counter the ldquoglobal bullying directed at her.In the letter the duchess begged her father, who lives in Mexico, to stop giving interviews and communicating with the press, and to leave her and Harry ldquoin peace.According to leaked excerpts leaked to the Press, she wrote: ldquoYour actions have broken my heart into a million pieces ndash not simply because you have manufactured such unnecessary and unwarranted pain, but by making the choice to not tell the truth as you are puppeteered in this. Something I will never understand.The duchess also criticised her father for the lies of his ldquoother daughter ndash Samantha Grant, who is the duchessrsquos half-sister.ldquoI pleaded with you to stop reading the tabloids. title: theresa-may-accused-of-running-down-the-clock-on-brexit
story: Addressing the House of Commons a fortnight after MPs voted for her to go back to Brussels and replace the controversial Irish border backstop, Mrs May acknowledged that she would need "some time" to hold talks with the EU.:MPs must hold their nerve over Brexit says Theresa MayShe said that a planned Commons debate on Thursday will be on an amendable motion reaffirming the Houses decision on January  that it supported the Governments efforts to find an alternative for the backstop and recognising that talks are ongoing.Mrs May pledged toto Parliament on February ,no deal has been secured before that time, to report back on progress and trigger a further MPs vote the following day."We now all need to hold our nerve to get the changes this House requires and deliver Brexit on time," Mrs May told the Commons."By getting the changes we need to the backstop by protecting and enhancing workers rights and environmental protections and by enhancing the role of Parliament in the next phase of negotiations I believe we can reach a deal that this House can support."We can deliver for the people and the communities that voted for change two-and-a-half years ago - and whose voices for too long have not been heard."We can honour the result of the referendum."And we can set this country on course for the bright future that every part of this United Kingdom deserves."That is this Governments mission. We shall not stint in our efforts to fulfil it."Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn accused the PM of "running down the clock" in the hope that MPs will be "blackmailed" by the fear of a no-deal Brexit into supporting "a deeply flawed deal".:Theresa May backs Chris Grayling after cancellation of ferry contract awarded to a firm with no ships"This is an irresponsible act," said Mr Corbyn. "She is playing for time and playing with peoples jobs, our economic security and the future of our industry."Mr Corbyn accused Mrs May of refusing to listen to his alternative deal, involving permanent customs union membership, a close alignment with the single market and matching EU workplace and environmental protections."I urge all members across this House to think about the damage the Prime Ministers strategy is doing - the threat to industry and skilled jobs in communities across Britain," he said."Now is not the time to stand idly by, now is the time to stand up and do the right thing: to rule out no deal and back Labours alternative plan."

title: background-music-is-a-human-rights-violation-say-campaigners
story: But background music has become the centre of a new campaign to support the elderly, hard of hearing or autistic people, as well as those who just find it annoying.The group Quiet Scotland argues that ldquopiped music, played by shops, cafes and restaurants can be ldquodistressing to people who would prefer a quieter environment.The campaign started in , and has around  members from around Scotland.It began as an offshoot of the Pipedown campaign, based in England, and initially campaigned against background music in Edinburgh.It has since expanded to cover the whole of Scotland, and publishes a list of ldquomuzac-free locations in Edinburgh and Glasgow, for other haters of background music to visit.The group also encourages retailers that eschew piped music to contact the group and be placed on the list. It says that playing loud music in public places amounts to a violation of human rights.Quiet Scotland has designed a set of feedback cards that allow customers to rate cafes, restaurants and bars on the loudness of their music.The cards are available from the group on request, and it hopes that they will persuade cafe owners and retailers to turn the music off. It also suggests that the grouprsquos followers contact the managers or owners of businesses to complain about the loudness of music.The pub chain Wetherspoons has already banned background music in its branches, and some supermarkets have introduced ldquoquiet hours where their music is switched off.Discount retailers Aldi and Lidl do not play any music in their branches.The Herald tested six venues in Glasgow with a decibel meter and found that one store ndash JD Sports ndash had music in its branch as loud as  decibels, which is as loud as a lawnmower. Its average was  decibels.By law, workers exposed to average noise levels of more than  decibels must be provided with ear protection.The Nike sports shop, which plays music in its branches, measured  on the decibel meter. Branches of Starbucks and Pizza Hut in the town centre, meanwhile, measured  and  decibels respectively.The Counting House Wetherspoons on George Square in Glasgow ndashwhich doesnrsquot play music ndash measured  decibels, the quietest venue tested.Quiet Scotlandrsquos treasurer, Anne Wellman, , said while the group began as an offshoot of Pipedown in England, they changed its name because ldquopiped music has a dferent meaning in Scotland.ldquoWe changed it to Quiet Scotland, because everybody who joined intensely dislikes background music played in public places, she said.ldquoSometimes thatrsquos because of health conditions, but in many cases itrsquos merely because we dislike having music imposed upon us.ldquoIn most cases, the music that shops and cafes play is unlikely to be popular with customers, she said. ldquoThink of the types of music you donrsquot like, and then have that blasted at you when yoursquore trying to eat. Because thatrsquos mostly the case.ldquoWhat are the odds of them playing something you actually like ldquoIt is very distressing for people who have a medical condition like autism or tinnitus or any hearing problems.She also suggested that disability legislation designed to protect those with medical conditions from discrimination could be applied to the loudness of music in public places.ldquoIt can actually affect your health and put you off going into shops and restaurants, she said.ldquoFor a lot of people, itrsquos simply annoying, but annoying to the point of refusing to patronise thoseshops.ldquoWe have about  members and we have a Facebook and Twitter presence which is gaining followers.ldquoI would make a comparison with the anti-smoking campaign. There was a point at which that was laughed at, and then it reached a tipping point when people actually started to agree.ldquoWe do see it as a transgression of a human right.The group also claims that rather than attracting more customers, loud background music can drive sales away, with customers preferring to shop online or in quieter places.Even pubs that choose not to playmusic can have televisions or gambling machines that make conversation dficult, it says.Background music has drawn the attention of celebrities, including Joanna Lumley, Stephen Fry and Roger Scruton, the conservative intellectual.

title: st-mirren-vow-to-find-and-ban-fans-who-spat-at-unconscious-supporter
story: Buddies chiefs have hit out at the "completely and utterly unacceptable" behaviour of a small group of fans on Saturday.The United supporter was injured while celebrating one of the Ladbrokes Championship outfits goals during their - win in Paisley.But in a statement posted on the Saints website, club officials claim he was targeted by a section of the home support as he was being led away for treatment.Read more:Police Scotland accused of trying to turn young football fans into paid informants"On Saturday a Dundee Utd supporter suffered a serious head injury after the away crowd surged forward after Uniteds first goal," the statement said. We cannot allow the actions of a very small number of fans to ruin the reputation of St Mirren Football Club."Some of the people responsible were identied but unfortunately the quality of the CCTV footage of the incident is such that at this time we are unable to pursue this to the degree of certainty that would allow prosecution."If we are able to clearly identy the culprits, regardless of what happens in a legal sense, they will be given a letime ban from our stadium.Read more:Police warning to football fans over crackdown on coin-throwing"We would ask anyone with any information or footage of the incident to contact the club on info@stmirren."Any information provided will be treated in the strictest confidence."For the avoidance of any doubt antisocial behaviour will not be tolerated in ANY area of our stadium."A spokeswoman for Police Scotland said: "We were contacted by the club about an incident and enquiries are ongoing."

story: The drinks giantrsquos plan, now lodged with City of Edinburgh Council, will create around  jobs and also see the upgrade of visitor facilities at distilleries which provide the malts for the Johnnie Walker blend.:Diageos whisky tourism centre plan for former House of Fraser in Princes Street unveiledDiageo said it is moving to invest over pound million in a series of ldquoScotch whisky experiences which includes revamping its existing  distillery visitor attractions and a poundm layout to reopen the ldquoiconic distilleries of Port Ellen and Brora.The Edinburgh planning application, jointly submitted by Diageo and the building owner Parabola, sets out proposals for a seven-floor visitor centre. title: watch-ian-blackford-brands-theresa-may-liar-in-heated-commons-exchange
story: The SNP leader at Westminster was responding to the Prime Minister as she updated MPs on the revived talks with Brussels in her bid to get the backstop changed.He initially claimed Mrs May was living in a ldquoparallel universe and when she laughed, the Highland MP declared: ldquoShe sits there laughing. Sometimes you should be honest with yourself, never mind being honest with the people of the United Kingdom.As the Tory benches expressed their disapproval at his tone, Mr Blackford continued, accusing the PM of living in a ldquoBrexit fantasy.ldquoWe are  days from Scotland being dragged out of the European Union against our will,  days from economic catastrophe, he declared.Branding her deal a ldquofraud, and calling on her to extend the Article  process, the Highland MP questioned whether the Government had undertaken an economic impact analysis on her deal.When Mrs May rose to insist such an analysis had been published, Mr Blackford shouted out: ldquoNot true.After John Bercow, the Commons Speaker, intervened to insist the PM must be heard, she suggested by his interruption the SNP leader might have ldquoinadvertently misled the House.At this point, Mr Blackford shouted out: ldquoLiar.As Tory MPs reacted angrily and pointed their fingers at the Nationalist MP, Mr Bercow rose to ldquoask the right honourable gentleman to withdraw that word. He cannot accuse another Member in this House of dishonesty. Withdraw.ldquoIn courtesy to yourself, I withdraw, said the SNP leader to cries of dissatisfaction from the Conservative benches.But the Speaker intervened again to say there were plenty of precedents for such a response, including doing it once himself, adding: ldquoThat is enough.Mrs May rose to insist again an economic analysis of her deal had been published and added that Mr Blackfordrsquos assertion that Scotland should be independent of the UK might raise cheers on the SNP benches but it would, she insisted, ldquonot raise cheers from those people in Scotland whose economic future depends on[Scotland] being a member of the UK.Later, Tory backbencher Stephen Kerr condemned Mr Blackford for his ldquoboorish behaviour and ldquocrass nonsense.The Stirling MP added: ldquoPeople are sick and tired of the SNP and their contrived approach to politics, full of grievance and pettiness. title: broadcasting-watchdog-should-investigate-bbc-news-operation-cairncross-review-says
story: His comments came as the government-commissioned Cairncross Review called on Ofcom to explore the impact of the BBCrsquos news coverage on journalism and said the corporation should do more to share its technical and digital expertise.The review headed by Dame Frances Cairncross was not asked to comment on the role of the BBC but chose to do so after hearing concerns from many of those in the publishing industry that the corporationrsquos news coverage cuts across efforts to establish a viable future for public service journalism.Mr McLellan welcomed the decision by the review to highlight the issues which were raised in evidence sessions. ldquoGiven that Ofcom dismissed our concerns when we raised them around the proposals for the new BBC Scotland channel, this is most welcome, he said. ldquoAn overall examination of what the BBC offers is overdue, evenit only disproves our concerns. These questions are serious and they need proper consideration and scrutiny.He said the BBCrsquos provision of news coverage online for free was making it dficult for news publishers to sell content and subscriptions, and could be undermining funding for journalism as a result. ldquoNobody argues that the BBCrsquos content is not good, butit is always free it is dficult for commercial publishers to establish a sound basis to operate, he said. ldquoThe BBC, funded by the licence-payer, has been abusing its monopoly.Mr McLellan said the BBC was operating in areas, including long-form written journalism which was nothing to do with its core role. A lot of the written material it produces is in direct competition with commercial news providers and is not part of its coreas a public service broadcaster. Much of the material the BBC is publishing now is independent of their programming. You see it in sport every weekend, he said.ldquoThere are many factors affecting us in publishing and the BBCrsquos online operation is only one of them. Changing that itself is not going to change the basic issue of the monopolising of advertising revenues by the tech giants, but it doesnrsquot help us when we are trying to construct viable alternatives.The Shawcross report does not make a judgement about the extent to which the BBCrsquos online coverage is harming the press. But the review ldquourges the BBC to think more carefully about how its news provision can act as a complement to, rather than a substitute for commercial news.Meanwhile, it adds: ldquoOfcom should assess whether BBC News Online is striking the right balance between aiming for the widest reach for its own content on the one hand and driving traffic from its online site to commercial publisherson the other, and says ldquothe BBC should do more to share its technical and digital expertise for the benefit of local publishers.Critics have questioned to what extent news coverage of TV lsquoeventsrsquo like Love Island and Irsquom a Celebrity Get Me Out of Here should be a part of its role as a public service broadcaster, but the BBC argues a erse spread of material is essential in order to reach all audiences, particularly young people.The BBC also funds Local Democracy Reporters under a scheme which provides publishers with reporters to enhance coverage of councils and other local issues. The review calls for an expansion of the scheme. However it has been dficult to recruit candidates in some areas. Mr McLellan welcomed this suggestion and said the principle had been established but added: ldquoThe strengths of the programme now need to be built on and the weaknesses tackled.In response to the review the Culture secretary Jeremy Right said:The BBC offers the very thing that this Review aims to encourage: a source of reliable and high quality news, with a focus on objectivity and impartiality, and independent from government. However, it is right that the role of the BBC, as a Public Service Broadcaster, is appropriately transparent and clear.A spokesman for the BBC said there was no evidence of the BBC ldquocrowding out other providers. ldquoItrsquos vital that people of all ages have access to impartial news which is relevant to them, and we provide younger audiences with a wide range of stories, he said. ldquo Wersquore happy to look at what more we can do to share our technical and digital expertise for the benefit of local publishers, but as the review itself says, any curtailing of the BBCrsquos news offering would be counter-productive.

title: brexit-theresa-may-accused-of-showing-contempt-for-democracy
story: When an international treaty - like the proposed Withdrawal Agreement with the EU - is signed, by law MPs should have  days to scrutinise its details before it is implemented.But the Prime Minister told MPs that they already knew the details of the Withdrawal Agreement, only a few of which, relating to the backstop, she was seeking to change.Therefore, the  days of scrutiny were not needed and the Government would seek to scrap the provision in this instance through the Withdrawal Agreement Bill once a new deal with Brussels had been struck.Mrs May explained: "While we will follow normal procedurewe can, where there is insufficient time remaining after the meaningful vote, we will make provision in the Withdrawal Agreement Bill, with Parliaments consent, to ensure we are able to raty on time to guarantee our exit in an orderly way."However, for many MPs this reference to ldquoinsufficient time raised the prospect that the PM will seek to hold the meaningful vote on her Plan B just days before exit day on March ."This plan shows contempt for our democracy, declared Labourrsquos Paul Blomfield. ldquoThe Government is trying to avoid proper scrutiny and run down the clock in order to force through its bad Brexit deal Labour will oppose this change, which would deny Parliament full scrutiny."Layla Moran, the Liberal Democrat MP, speaking on behalf of the pro-EU Best for Britain campaign, accused Mrs May of a ldquocynical and undemocratic move, adding: "May will stop at nothing to crowbar through her botched Brexit deal eventhat means ripping up the Statute Book and subverting parliamentary scrutiny and process.Just hours after yet another Commons statement on the EU withdrawal process, Labour began its bid to stop the PM from ldquorecklessly running down the clock a claim she denied.Jeremy Corbyn tabled an amendment for tomorrowrsquos debate and vote on Brexit aimed at forcing Mrs May to hold a meaningful vote by the end of the month.ldquoThis amendment would stop the Government from running down the clock on the Brexit negotiations, hoping MPs can be blackmailed into supporting a botched deal. This is an act of gross irresponsibility, declared the Labour leader.However, the expectation is that this amendment will fail and so-called ldquoHigh Noon will take place with the third indicative vote, due on February .Yesterday evening, Labourrsquos Yvette Cooper published a new bill to force a decision by mid-March to avoid Britain crashing out of the EU on March  without a deal.The Yorkshire MP will put forward her amendment for debate and a vote on February  when some ministers, including a number in the Cabinet, might be prepared to resign rather than be part of a government that was allowing Britain to plunge over the Brexit clf-edge. Early indications are that Ms Cooper could expect more Tory support than her unsuccessful effort last month.She said: "This bill creates a parliamentary safeguard to prevent us drting into no-deal by accident and to prevent those crucial decisions being left until the final fortnight."Yesterday during the PMrsquos update to MPs, Mr Corbyn made a direct appeal to Cabinet ministers to rebel to stop a no-deal outcome.He said: ldquoNo minister, serious about protecting jobs in this country, would allow a prime minister to deliberately run down the clock and play chicken with peoples livelihoods. To stand by and do nothing would be a complete dereliction of duty."Earlier, Mrs May called on MPs to "hold their nerve" and come together behind an EU withdrawal deal which would deliver Brexit on schedule in  daysrsquo time.She insisted she believed the Government could get the necessary changes to the backstop and honour the referendum result in full to ldquoset this country on course for the bright future that every part of this United Kingdom deserves.She added: ldquoThat is this Governments mission. We shall not stint in our efforts to fulfil it."In other developments:*David Lidington, the PMrsquos de facto deputy, and Stephen Barclay, the Brexit Secretary, were in Strasbourg for talks with MEPs and other senior figures at the European Parliament*Jeremy Hunt, the Foreign Secretary, was in Paris for Brexit discussions with his French counterpart Jean-Yves Le Drian*the European Commission suggested trains would be allowed to continue to run through the Channel Tunnel for three months in the event of a no-deal Brexit*Mark Carney, the Governor of the Bank of England, urged politicians to find a Brexit solution as he warned over economic risks posed by the slowing Chinese economy, protectionism and "de-globalisation"*leading Tory Remainer Nicky Morgan said cross-party agreement on a Brexit deal was not possible and urged the PM to face the "reality of the parliamentary arithmetic" after the "tenor" of Mr Corbyns dismissive response to the lack of progress on reaching a Brexit deal*Mike Cherry of the Federation of Small Businesses said: "By asking for a further two weeks to try and renegotiate a deal with the EU, the Government has simply called for further business uncertainty and political paralysis," and*Andrea Leadsom, the Commons Leader, said Brexiteers should not be "purist" about the type of deal Mrs May could secure on the Northern Ireland backstop.

title: virtual subsea work for meldrum pupils
story: Meldrum Academy pupils have taken part in OPITO#s Energise Your Futureevent.The academy was one of eight north east schools to have taken part in the initiative that was held during the final day of Subsea Expo at the Aberdeen Exhibition and Conference Centre on Thursday, February .EYF is managed by OPITO, the global, not-for-profit, skills body for the energy industry.The event aims to inspire and encourage more young people in the UK to consider the industry as a career choice by providing a chance to get up close with key companies and people who can help explain their businesses as well as roles and routes into the sector.This year,  companies were involved in the Subsea Expo programme.Marine engineering firm EC-OG offered pupils the chance to use its latest virtual reality technology which will transport them subsea to inspect its subsea power hub and battery equipment.John McDonald, OPITO CEO, said: “As more and more oil and gas companies embrace new techniques such as virtual reality and articial intelligence, it is important that young people see and hear first-hand what the future of the industry looks like and the vast and exciting opportunities these developments present to them.”Attracting young talent remains a key focus for the sector.The recent OPITO UKCS Workforce Dynamics Review showed thatthe sector achieves its ambitions set out in Vision ,, people will need to be recruited over the next two decades.Around , of those are expected to be in roles that don’t yet exist.Mr McDonald added: “We are currently developing a new UKCS Skills Strategy to support the skills that will be required by both new and existing personnel operating in the North Sea into the next decade.“It is important we provide opportunities through initiatives like EYF to help young people discover that this is a sector with a future worth considering that also has the learning infrastructure in place to help develop their career and unlock their potential.”The pupils taking part were all aged between  to . The other schools at the event were Aberdeen Grammar, the International School Aberdeen, Oldmachar Academy, Albyn School, Mintlaw Academy, Robert Gordon’s College and Peterhead Academy.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Jemima Adeoye, Director of Education and Childrens Services Laurence Findlay, Elizabeth Lyall, Cooper Masson, Cllr Gillian Owen, Cllr Jim Gford, Provost Bill Howatson, Chief Executive Jim Savege, Tami Fadeyi, Ruaridh Cumming and Head Teacher Pamela Farquhar with pupils outside the new Kinellar School"  Community celebrates official opening of Kinellar School viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: inspectors praise north east nursery
story: Education inspectors have expressed confidence in the ongoing improvements being made at Rothienorman Pre-School Nursery.A recent visit led to the village hall facility being described as a “welcome and nurturing environment” and Inspectors said children were “happy, enthusiastic, and developing confidence”.Key strengths included a “dedicated team” which inspectors said have developed positive relationships and a “strong sense of community”.But the nursery has been asked to improve in certain areas, including increased use of national guidance to develop a “robust and rigorous approach to self-evaluation”. Inspectors said this will enable practitioners to identy what is working well and what needs to improve.They also want to see development of approaches to assessment and planning to help improve the quality of learning experiences and provide “greater depth and challenge” for all children.Improvements are also being sought in the development of practitioners’ knowledge and understanding of how to support children’s early language and mathematical thinking.Inspectors are confident that the setting has the capacity to continue to improve and will make no more visits in connection with this inspection.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The group at the summit of Oxen Craig - Craig Thomson is pictured th left"  Craig ascends Bennachie  times viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: strong entry of calves for spring show
story: Some of the best commercial calves in the country will be forward at the Royal Northern Spring Show, held in conjunction with Aberdeen and Northern Marts.The annual event, which will be held at the Thainstone Centre on Wednesday, February , has attracted a strong entry of  calves from noted breeders.John and Craig Robertson from Newton of Logierait, Pitlochry, regularly dominate the show and sale, having scooped the supreme championship six times since . Last year, they sold the top price animal at £, for their champion heer and sold three others for £,, £, and £,.This year, the Robertsons have  calves entered including a full sister to last year’s top price heer.Huntly and Insch duo, Blair Duffton and Rebecca Stuart, will alsoto this year’s event with five calves, as will Ian Miller of Miller Farms, North Lurg, Midmar, who has four calves entered.Judging the commercial cattle entries, which will occur following the show and sales of bulls, will be well-known pedigree and commercial producer, Melanie Alford.John Angus, head of livestock at Thainstone, said: “The livestock sale element of the Royal Northern Spring Show is a fast-growing part of the event and we are delighted to be working once again with the Royal Northern Agricultural Society. The Spring Show is now recognised as the number one place for buyers from near and far to come and source quality calves with further showing potential.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"DIGG Councillor Martin Ford"  Councillors keen to prevent cuts viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Wednesday  Feb  : AM

title: blocking the bus in the hope
story: Police Scotland and Orkney Islands Council are asking drivers to ‘think bus’ when leaving vehicles in St Margaret’s Hope.The X service is frequently prevented from travelling through the village when stationary cars and vans block the narrow entrance to the Back Road from Pier Road and Cromarty Square.“If the bus can’t travel along the Back Road it has to take the new road instead and passengers waiting in the village miss their bus,” said East Mainland, South Ronaldsay and Burray councillor, Steve Sankey.“It’s a growing problem and something bus users and the local community council have raised with me. People expect a reliable service and I can understand their frustration. We’re joining with the Police in asking drivers not to block the way into the Back Road and find somewhere  to park that doesn’t affect the bus.”Chief Inspector Matt Webb, Police Scotland Area Commander for Orkney, said: “We will take actionvehicles are left in ways which restrict the passage of the local bus service.“We would rather not do thatpossible # and I would encourage drivers to be considerate and play their part in making sure buses can move freely through the narrow streets of the village.”If you have any comments or feedback on bus services, please contact the Transportation Team at the Council at transport@orkney.gov.uk or  . title: german company revealed as third bidder for northern isles ferry tender
story: INTERNATIONAL ferry company FRS Group have been revealed as the third bidder for the Northern Isles ferry service.The company, headquartered in Flensburg, Germany, confirmed the news this week.#FRS follows the tender process. But please understand that we will not disclose any further information on this tender at this time.#It was last month that the Scottish Government stated that an invitation to tender for the next contract to run the Northern Isles ferry services had been issued to three bidders.The names of the companies involved were not released by the government, however Serco NorthLink and Calmac did confirm their involvement.When asked last month, previous bidder Streamline confirmed that it was not one of the bidders on this occasion, leading to speculation over the final company involved.Submission of final tenders is scheduled for March, with a view to awarding the contract in July, said the Scottish Government. The contract is estimated to be worth £m, and will run for eight years.FRS Group runs ferry services throughout many areas of the world, including Europe, North Africa, the Middle East and North America.The organisation is also involved in maritime consultancy and offshore logistics.According to the company, FRS has grown from a regional passenger ferry operator into an internationally active group with  vessels and more than , employees from more than a dozen countries all over the world.FRS annually carries . million passengers and . million vehicles on its numerous national and international shipping lines.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: interactive hie roadshow comes to orkney
story: newsInteractive HIE roadshow comes to OrkneyFebruary ,  at : pm vw, px"  Starting here in Orkney this week, Highlands and Islands Enterprise is hitting the road to teach people how to outsmart online criminals and spot cyber threats.The free Cyber Sense on Tour workshops will visit businesses and communities throughout the Highlands and Islands using fun, interactive games to allow participants to get under the skin of hackers and learn the tricks of the trade.The tour starts in Orkney with two events, the first at Orkney Library this Tuesday, February , and the second at the NorthLink ferry Hamnavoe at the Stromness terminal on Wednesday.The interactive experience is open to all and will use innovative technology to create an immersive ‘point of view’ exercise, were participants can take the role of an employee, a cyber security professional and even a hacker to learn the tricks of the trade.Concepts such as ‘phishing’ will be explained and audiences will be taught to spot scams, dissect spurious emails and prevent hackers taking over their online lives.Working in collaboration with the National Cyber Security Centreand supported by the Scottish Government, the Cyber Sense sessions will provide a memorable and engaging way to discover how everyday actions can help protect people and companies from these evolving cyber dangers.April Conroy, project manager at Highland and Islands Enterprise, said: “As the way we work and live becomes more integrated online, it can be easy to take for granted how much important information we upload to the internet. Whether it’s our personal information on social media or important financial details, it’s vital that we’re aware of how to keep our safe and secure from cyber criminals.”“By really getting under the skin of these hackers, our Cyber Sense workshops can point out how to understand how these iniduals work. Through the games we’ve designed, attendees will be able to competitively play roles on both sides of a cyber-crime. This offers a unique perspective that can show just what preventative measures can be taken to outsmart these online criminals.”To learn more about the Cyber Sense on Tour event and to book a free place, visit www.hellodigital.scot cyber-sense- copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. story: Councillors held discussions today with the Scottish Government constitutional relations secretary Michael Russell MSP over the potential impact on Orkney of the Brexit process.Mr Russell, who is leading the Scottish Government’s Brexit preparations, accepted an invitation from Orkney Islands Council leader James Stockan to visit the county and meet with councillors and senior officials.Following the meeting Councillor Stockan described the talks as #an extremely useful engagement# with Mr Russell.He added: #Everybody got the chance to ask questions today, including some dficult questions, and we had answers that were really worthwhile in an Orkney context.#What we hope is that he will leave with, is a real flavour of the challenge, whatever happens, there will be for us in Orkney.#copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney youth conference takes place
story: Orkney#s biennial Youth Conference, held at the Kirkwall Town Hall yestrday, organised by the OIC#s Community Learning and Development Service, brought together  young people from across Orkney to take part in workshops and hear from keynote speakers on a range of issues.The conference was opened by council Convener Harvey Johnston, who said he was truly delighted and privileged to be at the conference, amongst Orkney#s young people.He continued: #Our young folk are Orkney#s greatest asset and I#m expecting great things from you all. Not just today at this conference, but in your lives to come.#Taking to the stage next was keynote speaker John Loughton. John is a high profile and award winning global youth leader, social entrepreneur, campaigner and leadership speaker. He is founder and CEO of global leadership company DareLead. In  he was elected the youngest ever Chair of the Scottish Youth Parliament.On the back of yesterday#s Orkney Youth Conference, local folk in Orkney who work with children and young people, are gathering today for the third Growing Up in Orkney conference.Today’s conference gives them the opportunity to share and learn from each other as well as find out what’s working well in our communities. It’s also about learning from others and exploring practice further afield and deciding what to stop doing, what we should be doing more of and what we should start doing.Delegates will take part in a range of workshops and hear from keynote speaker Dave Clubb. Dave who hails from Shetland is a Social Worker with  years experience in dferent positions within the Shetland Islands Council before working for five years on a freelance basis and becoming a foster carer. vw, px"  copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: power cable fault results in rackwick work
story: A faulty power cable, which links Orkney with mainland Scotland, has resulted in work being carried out at Rackwick Bay in Hoy.A Scottish and Southern Energy Networks spokesman said: “SSEN can confirm there is a network fault affecting one of the two electricity distribution cables that connect Orkney to the Scottish mainland. Following a fault investigation process, damage has been located to a section of the Pentland Firth East cable near the shore at Rackwick Bay, Hoy.“There is no impact to customer supplies on Orkney as a result of the fault and contingency measures are in place, including the potential operation of the backup power station at Kirkwall, supported by mobile generation sets, to ensure a safe and secure supply of electricity for customers.“SSEN is committed to ing the network to normal operation as soon as possible and has instigated a repair plan. Following the receipt of the necessary permissions from statutory authorities late last week, work to undertake a sectional cable replacement is now under way.#The statement added: #It is expected this work, which will be contingent on tidal flows and weather conditions, will be complete early next week, with the line re-energised shortly after.“As part of SSEN’s subsea cable inspection and replacement programme, a project to progress an end-to-end replacement of the Pentland Firth East distribution cable is already at an advanced stage of development, with cable installation and commissioning currently due to take place in autumn next year.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: survey project sheds new light on hms royal oak
story: A VOLUNTEER e team has been granted permission to extensively survey the official wargrave of HMS Royal Oak in Scapa Flow.New D photogrammetry techniques are being used and still photography and videography will allow the team to capture and share the spirit of the site.In the early hours of October , , U’s commander Günther Prien guided her silently into Scapa Flow, and launched a torpedo attack, In just a few minutes, Royal Oak was gone.  sailors perished, including over  boy seamen.Ahead of the th anniversary of her loss later this year, a team of volunteer civilian ers has been granted permission to e the wreck by the secretary of state for defence.This is part of a collaboration with the Royal Oak Association and the Royal Navy to document the last resting place of the men who lost their lives, so their passing can be remembered and preserved for future generations.The project aims to ensure that HMS Royal Oak is not forgotten, by sharing imagery with relatives of those lost, as well as the wider public.The survey team is using state-of-the-art underwater imagery techniques, in order to produce high-quality photography and video. In addition, D photogrammetry is taking place so that digital D models of the wreck can be produced. By using these techniques, in essence, the team is able to digitally bring HMS Royal Oak to the surface.Survey organiser and licence-holder Emily Turton said: “The wreck of HMS Royal Oak is the final resting place of  men and boys. As the most intact underwater dreadnought-era battleship, she has an architectural grandeur befitting of any national memorial. However, at the smaller end of the scale, artefacts pertaining to everyday le on board are scattered around the site, bringing home the human story of those lost. The site is peaceful, yet vibrant, and supports a thriving marine eco-system. It is both an honour and a privilege to get to know the site.”Full details and further pictures in The Orcadian this week.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: team appointed for 4 5m north isles landscape partnership scheme
story: The North Isles Landscape Partnership Schemeteam is now up to full strength with the appointment of three new staff members.Anne Bignall, Valerie Dawson, Claire Wilson and programme manager Andy Golightly will work with communities on the North Isles to deliver projects that will promote the heritage, landscape and culture of the area.Working with the communities on the North Isles the NILPS will deliver projects that will promote the heritage, landscape and culture of the area.Funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund, the scheme will support Orkney’s North Isles through the delivery of a number of projects that includes traditional skills training, educational programmes, wildle recording and enhancement of isles heritage centres amongst others.The programme will invest £. million in the North Isles and the project will run until .Mr Golightly said “It’s great to now have the team in place so we can concentrate on delivering the projects in the isles, a lot of work has been done getting to this point and now the focus will be working with the isles communities to start getting things done on the ground.#One of the first things that will be available is the North Isles Landscape Partnership Heritage Grants. Small grants will be available that contribute to the aims and objectives of the NILPS programme. Groups and organisations can apply for grants of up to £ to support projects, activities and events in the isles.Valerie Dawson, NILPS project officer added: “The Heritage Grants are open to applicants now and we would encourage any not for profit organisations, with any ideas related to heritage, that might require funding to contact us to seewe can help.”The project team can be contacted on or email the North Isles Landscape Partnership scheme or visit their website www.nilpscopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: update kirkwall town centre roadworks
story: newsUPDATE: Kirkwall town centre roadworksFebruary ,  at : am vw, px"  Work is set to continue next week on street improvements in Kirkwall#s town centre.There will be further repaving on the area around the TSB bank, on the junction between Castle Street and Broad Street, with a one-way system remaining in place.Orkney Islands Council has said once this initial stage is completed, work will then move to the entrance to Albert Street, meaning the street will be closed to traffic from Laing Street. It#s anticipated this work will start on February  and could take four weeks to complete.The current one-way system means drivers can turn into Castle Street from Junction Road and on into Broad Street but vehicles do not have access from Palace Road into Broad Street.A signed ersion via Clay Loan is in place. In addition, vehicles cannot turn into Castle Street from Albert Street – but can drive on into Broad Street.The works are part of the Kirkwall Townscape Heritage Initiative’sPlaces and Spaces project, which will see improvements to the area at the bottom of the Strynd, the creation of a new path to the War Memorial at St Magnus and improvements at the head of Victoria Street.The council has said the works at the top of Castle Street will see new paving and road surfacing laid, and the road surface raised to pavement level. This initial phase of the project is due for completion early May after which works will be suspended for the main summer season.Work at the entrance to Victoria Street is set to begin in the autumn, with a suspension planned, in December for Christmas shopping season.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: views sought on cursiter quarry expansion plans
story: Orkney Islands Council is providing a further opportunity for the public to view and comment on plans to expand Cursiter Quarry in Firth.The Council is due to submit a planning application for the long-term development of Cursiter Quarry in Firth this Spring.As part of a -phased expansion plan designed to secure additional reserves the quarry could increase in size over the next three decades expanding into neighbouring fields. The planning application also covers landscaping and future restoration of the site.The application process is being handled by consultants AECOM.The council-owned quarry currently supplies stone and aggregate materials for Council roads and building projects as well as the local construction industry.  It extracts Devonian Flagstone which is highly suited to a range of crushed aggregate products, in particular as roadstone and aggregates, used for producing asphalt for road construction and maintenance, with the quarry being the only active producer of asphalt in Orkney.The activity at the quarry generates an income for the Council which is reinvested to provide and protect some of the vital services we provide in Orkney.The current quarry area is heading towards the end of its use and an expansion would safeguard supply of materials. Current output ranges between , and , tonnes of rock per year andapproved, the ha expansion will release approximately  million tonnes of additional resources, sufficient for another  years of production.Full details are available on the Council website at http:www.orkney.gov.uk Council C long-term-development-of-cursiter-quarry-in-firth.htmPersons wishing to provide comments on the proposed development can do so by writing to AECOM at fraser.blackwood@aecom or by post to Fraser Blackwood, APEX ,  Haymarket Terrace, Edinburgh, EH HD by  February .OIC says that, at this stage, comments made to Aecom are for the purposes of assisting with the scheme design and EIA process and as such are not representations to the Planning Authority. When the planning application is submitted, an opportunity will be given for representations to be made to the Planning Authority.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Dingwall sale brings lots of joy to charities
story: CHARITIES which help Highland cancer patients in their time of need will share a pound, windfall from a special auction in Dingwall.The event at Dingwall Auction Mart had originally been put together to raise funds for Beauly mother-of-two Roz Paterson who had been aiming to secure pound, to fund potentially le-saving treatment in the United States,Her condition has proved resistant to several forms of chemotherapy leaving her facing a race against the clock to try and access expensive Car-T cell therapy in Boston.When it emerged that her treatment will now be funded on the NHS much closer to home, a decision was taken that the mart auction would go ahead ndash with four key Highland charities benefiting instead.Supporters of the Raising for Roz campaign had come up trumps with more than  lots put forward.The go-ahead for the auction provided a welcome boost for Highland Hospice, Marie Curie, MacMillan Nurses and Maggiersquos Highland.The star lot was a wedding package worth pound, which was snapped up by Inverness couple Alison Ireland and Christian Kenway for pound.Auction organiser Willie Matheson hailed the full-house auction a great success. He said: ldquoThe star lot was the wedding package which was quite unique and went to a local girl.
